https://openalex.org/A5100606557.title: Director
https://openalex.org/A5100606557.ai_summary: Paul M. Thompson is the Director of the Imaging Genetics Center at the University of Southern California. His research focuses on neuroimaging and computational analysis to understand brain structure, function, and disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease. He has developed and applied advanced machine learning and deep learning methods, including novel segmentation techniques and federated learning models, to analyze MRI and diffusion tensor imaging data for predicting disease progression and cognitive decline. His work also encompasses brain imaging genomics and the creation of population-specific brain atlases to enhance neuroimaging studies.

https://openalex.org/A5012412464.ai_summary: Alex Mihailidis is a researcher specializing in the development and evaluation of assistive technologies for older adults, particularly those with dementia. His work focuses on ambient-assisted living systems that use artificial intelligence, computer vision, and sensor technologies to support independence, monitor behavioral symptoms, and reduce caregiver burden. He has contributed to designing privacy-aware video-based anomaly detection, wearable sensor data analysis for agitation detection, and automatic speech and language assessment methods for dementia. Additionally, Mihailidis has explored sensor-based systems for early frailty detection, aiming to improve quality of life and safety in home and care settings.

https://openalex.org/A5040631126.ai_summary: Jeffrey Kaye's research focuses on the use of digital technologies and unobtrusive home-based sensor systems to assess aging-related changes, particularly in cognitive function and early-stage dementia. His work includes developing continuous, ecologically valid methods to monitor gait, activity patterns, and spoken language to identify mild cognitive impairment and dementia-related care needs. Kaye also investigates the integration of technology in dementia care, including ethical considerations around companion robots and remote monitoring tools. His studies emphasize tailoring technology use to improve detection, care planning, and research participation among older adults.

https://openalex.org/A5051401339.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5051401339.org: University of California at Los Angeles
https://openalex.org/A5051401339.ai_summary: Bijan Najafi, Professor of Surgery at the University of California at Los Angeles, specializes in using wearable sensor technology to study frailty and related conditions in older adults. His research focuses on objectively assessing physical function, gait, balance, and physical activity patterns to identify and differentiate frailty levels, predict fall risk, and evaluate conditions such as cognitive frailty and chemotherapy resilience. Najafi’s work includes developing algorithms and wearable systems for remote and in-home monitoring, enabling early detection and intervention for frailty and its components across diverse patient populations. His studies highlight the potential of digital biomarkers and machine learning to facilitate telehealth applications in geriatric care and chronic disease management.

https://openalex.org/A5063630764.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5063630764.ai_summary: John C. Morris is a Professor of Pathology and Immunology affiliated with the Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative. His research focuses on the early detection, progression, and characterization of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) through clinical, neuroimaging, and biomarker approaches. He has contributed to the development of sensitive cognitive and informant-based measures to distinguish very mild dementia from normal aging, and has explored the relationship between sleep disturbances, amyloid deposition, and AD pathology. Additionally, Morris’s work employs advanced machine learning and multi-omics techniques to analyze molecular signatures, driving behavior patterns, and neuroimaging data to improve prediction, diagnosis, and understanding of preclinical and autosomal dominant forms of AD.

https://openalex.org/A5048196698.title: Scientific Director
https://openalex.org/A5048196698.ai_summary: Luigi Ferrucci is a Scientific Director at the National Institute on Aging whose research focuses on the biological, physiological, and clinical aspects of aging. His work includes advancing the understanding of frailty, multimorbidity, and the molecular mechanisms underlying age-related decline in physical and cognitive functions. Ferrucci has contributed to studies on the relationship between sensory loss, physical activity, muscle function, and aging, as well as the development of biomarkers and interventions to promote healthy aging. His research integrates epidemiologic, molecular, and geroscience perspectives to improve diagnosis, treatment, and care for older adults.

https://openalex.org/A5000937401.ai_summary: Dinggang Shen's research focuses on the development and application of advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques for medical image analysis, particularly in neurodegenerative disease diagnosis such as Alzheimer's disease (AD). His work emphasizes automatic feature learning from multimodal imaging data like MRI, PET, and functional MRI, enabling early detection, differential diagnosis, and progression prediction of cognitive impairments including mild cognitive impairment (MCI). He has contributed methods integrating anatomical and demographic data, employing novel network architectures to identify discriminative brain regions and predict clinical outcomes. Overall, his research advances computer-aided diagnosis systems to improve understanding and management of brain disorders.

https://openalex.org/A5046120768.title: A.W. and Mary Margaret Clausen Distinguished Professor
https://openalex.org/A5046120768.ai_summary: Bruce L. Miller is the A.W. and Mary Margaret Clausen Distinguished Professor of Neurology at the University of California San Francisco. His research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases such as frontotemporal dementia and Alzheimer's disease, exploring neural network dysfunctions and their clinical manifestations using advanced imaging techniques. He has contributed to understanding language impairments in primary progressive aphasia variants and the neural basis of empathy loss in frontotemporal lobar degeneration. Additionally, Miller has been involved in developing AI-assisted technologies to improve care for individuals with dementia, including innovations for fall detection and post-fall management in memory care settings.

https://openalex.org/A5005099850.title: Professor of Radiology
https://openalex.org/A5005099850.ai_summary: Clifford R. Jack, Professor of Radiology at Mayo Medical School, specializes in neuroimaging research focused on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias. His work extensively employs advanced MRI techniques, including structural MRI, diffusion tensor imaging, and machine learning approaches, to improve diagnosis, track disease progression, and predict clinical outcomes in AD and mild cognitive impairment. He has contributed to the development and validation of imaging biomarkers, often integrating multimodal data, such as hippocampal volume and cerebrospinal fluid measures, to differentiate between healthy aging, MCI, and AD. Jack’s research also explores the utility of automated classification algorithms across multiple centers and imaging platforms, aiming to enhance clinical applicability and understanding of disease heterogeneity.

https://openalex.org/A5034999945.title: Asst
https://openalex.org/A5034999945.ai_summary: Christos Davatzikos, an Assistant Professor at the University of Pennsylvania, conducts research at the intersection of neuroimaging and machine learning to better understand brain diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, mild cognitive impairment, and neuropsychiatric disorders. His work focuses on developing novel computational methods for accurate in vivo quantification of brain structure and function, as well as interpretable machine learning models that capture disease heterogeneity and support precision diagnostics. By integrating multimodal MRI, genetic data, and fluid biomarkers, his research aims to enhance understanding of disease mechanisms, improve prediction of disease progression, and facilitate personalized treatment strategies. He has contributed methods for dimensionality reduction, disease subtyping, and risk scoring that leverage advanced AI and radiomics approaches in neuro-oncology and neurodegeneration.

https://openalex.org/A5019442831.ai_summary: Jeffrey M. Hausdorff's research focuses on the interplay between cognitive function—especially executive function and attention—and gait performance in aging and neurological conditions such as Parkinson's and Huntington's diseases. He explores gait variability as a marker for fall risk and disease severity, emphasizing the effects of dual-tasking and cognitive load on gait stability. Hausdorff also investigates neural connectivity underlying gait control and develops wearable sensor technologies and advanced statistical methods to remotely assess gait and predict health outcomes. His work spans fundamental studies of gait mechanisms to applications in clinical assessment and digital health monitoring.

https://openalex.org/A5021920622.ai_summary: Stefan Teipel's research focuses on the application of neuroimaging, neurochemical biomarkers, and advanced machine learning techniques for the early diagnosis and progression prediction of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative disorders. He has extensively studied imaging biomarkers such as MRI volumetry, functional connectivity, and diffusion tensor imaging to characterize structural and functional brain changes in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and AD. His work also includes developing explainable artificial intelligence frameworks, particularly convolutional neural networks, to assist clinical diagnosis by integrating neuroanatomical knowledge and enhancing interpretability. Additionally, Teipel explores ICT solutions, such as chatbot-based automated speech assessments, to support early detection and monitoring of cognitive decline.

https://openalex.org/A5079898540.title: Program Director, Healthcare Practice and Survivorship
https://openalex.org/A5079898540.ai_summary: Wendy Moyle is Program Director of Healthcare Practice and Survivorship at the Menzies Health Institute Queensland, Griffith University. Her research focuses on the use of social robots, such as PARO and humanoid robots, to enhance engagement, emotional well-being, and quality of life for older adults, particularly those living with dementia in long-term care settings. She has explored robotic interventions for reducing agitation, anxiety, pain, and social isolation, as well as the experiences of family caregivers during transitions to aged care. Moyle's work combines quantitative trials and qualitative approaches to evaluate the feasibility and benefits of technology-assisted dementia care.

https://openalex.org/A5018836358.title: Professor and Head of Department
https://openalex.org/A5018836358.org: UCL Institute of Neurology, University College London
https://openalex.org/A5018836358.ai_summary: Nick C. Fox is Professor and Head of the Department of Neurodegenerative Disease at the UCL Institute of Neurology, University College London. His research focuses on the use of advanced neuroimaging techniques, including structural MRI and machine learning, to improve diagnosis and differentiation of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, and related disorders. He has contributed to understanding the neuroanatomical and molecular underpinnings of dementia syndromes, exploring patterns of brain atrophy, proteinopathies, and network breakdown in neurodegeneration. Additionally, his work investigates environmental risk factors for dementia, such as air pollution, and seeks to enhance clinical diagnostic tools through imaging-based biomarkers and automated analyses.

https://openalex.org/A5025870220.ai_summary: Philip Scheltens’ research focuses on the application of advanced neuroimaging and electrophysiological methods to understand brain network alterations in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and other dementias. He has extensively utilized graph theoretical and multiplex network analyses of EEG and MEG data to reveal disruptions in functional connectivity and hub regions in AD, highlighting changes in frequency-specific brain networks. His work also explores biomarkers, cognitive reserve, and the integration of multimodal diagnostic measures using machine learning to improve differential diagnosis of dementias such as AD and dementia with Lewy bodies. Additionally, Scheltens has contributed to optimizing Alzheimer’s disease drug development by defining key factors for successful clinical trials.

https://openalex.org/A5102977342.ai_summary: Michael W. Weiner's research focuses on neuroimaging and biomarker development to understand and differentiate neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD), frontotemporal dementia, and mild cognitive impairment. He has extensively studied brain network connectivity, white matter changes using diffusion tensor imaging, and structural brain atrophy patterns to identify disease-specific signatures. His work also explores functional brain connectivity related to cognitive reserve and the use of advanced machine learning techniques to enhance the prediction of disease progression and diagnosis accuracy. Additionally, Weiner investigates the neurobiological bases of cognitive and behavioral symptoms in dementia, contributing to multimodal biomarker strategies for early detection and monitoring of disease.

https://openalex.org/A5014075642.title: Director
https://openalex.org/A5014075642.ai_summary: David A. Bennett is the Director of the Rush Alzheimer's Disease Center at Rush University Medical Center. His research primarily focuses on the neuropathology, clinical progression, and biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and aging-related cognitive decline. Bennett has contributed to understanding the relationship between AD pathology and subtle cognitive changes in non-demented individuals, the role of education and social activity in modifying cognitive outcomes, and the use of microRNAs and deep learning methods as novel diagnostic and prognostic tools. His work integrates longitudinal clinical-pathologic cohort studies with advanced molecular and computational techniques to enhance the assessment and prediction of cognitive impairment and dementia.

https://openalex.org/A5017168859.ai_summary: Rhoda Au's research focuses on the early detection and characterization of cognitive impairment and Alzheimer's disease using innovative biomarkers and machine learning techniques. Her work explores plasma amyloid-beta ratios, speech and voice acoustic features, and digital analysis of cognitive tasks such as the Clock Drawing Test to identify mild cognitive impairment and predict progression to dementia. She has advanced methods combining artificial intelligence with neuropsychological and imaging data to create accessible, noninvasive, and precise tools for screening and monitoring brain health. Au’s studies also emphasize the role of loneliness, depression, and heterogeneity in cognitive decline, advocating for precision health approaches tailored to individual needs.

https://openalex.org/A5026257338.title: Professor and Director, Center for Neuroimaging and Indiana Alzheimer's Disease Research Center
https://openalex.org/A5026257338.ai_summary: Andrew J. Saykin is a Professor and Director of the Center for Neuroimaging and the Indiana Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, Radiology and Imaging Sciences at Indiana University School of Medicine. His research focuses on Alzheimer's disease (AD) utilizing advanced neuroimaging techniques, machine learning, and deep learning methods to improve early detection, classification, and understanding of AD pathology. He has contributed to studies integrating multimodal imaging, microRNA network analyses, and biomarker evaluation to explore disease mechanisms and cognitive decline. Additionally, his work extends to understanding cognitive effects of chemotherapy and biological aging in oncology, emphasizing personalized approaches in neurological and cancer care.

https://openalex.org/A5064378373.ai_summary: Frederik Barkhof's research primarily focuses on the application of advanced neuroimaging techniques, such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), to study brain connectivity, structural integrity, and disease progression in neurological disorders including Alzheimer's disease, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes-related cognitive impairment. His work explores resting-state brain networks, cognitive and brain reserve effects, and the use of machine learning and explainable artificial intelligence for improved diagnosis and prognosis of dementia. He also investigates the reproducibility and clinical utility of quantitative MRI measures and imaging biomarkers to enhance disease monitoring and personalized patient care. Overall, his research integrates neuroimaging, computational methods, and clinical assessment to understand and track neurodegenerative and neuroinflammatory diseases.

https://openalex.org/A5014213472.title: Scientific Director
https://openalex.org/A5014213472.ai_summary: Agustín Ibáñez is the Scientific Director at Universidad Adolfo Ibañez, affiliated with Adolfo Ibáñez University. His research focuses on understanding cognition in naturalistic settings, exploring the complex interplay between brain networks, behavior, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and frontotemporal dementia. He leads multidisciplinary initiatives employing advanced neuroimaging, high-density EEG, and machine learning methods to improve dementia diagnosis, characterization, and care, particularly emphasizing diverse populations in Latin America. Ibáñez also contributes to regional efforts in brain health diplomacy and the development of collaborative frameworks to address challenges in dementia caregiving and research.

https://openalex.org/A5067755203.title: Honorary Consultant Physiotherapist
https://openalex.org/A5067755203.org: Newcastle Upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
https://openalex.org/A5067755203.ai_summary: Lynn Rochester is an Honorary Consultant Physiotherapist at Newcastle Upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust with extensive research focused on gait analysis, wearable technology, and physical activity monitoring in neurological conditions such as Parkinson’s disease (PD) and cognitive impairment. Her work explores the measurement of gait and mobility using accelerometers and wearable devices in real-world environments, aiming to improve disease assessment, fall risk evaluation, and intervention strategies. She has contributed to understanding the interplay between motor symptoms, physical activity patterns, and environmental factors across various populations, including older adults, people with PD, and those with cognitive decline both in community and care home settings. Rochester’s research also addresses validation of wearable technologies and develops frameworks for standardizing measurement protocols to enhance clinical and research applications.

https://openalex.org/A5032025339.title: Professor; Chief, Cognitive Neuroscience Division
https://openalex.org/A5032025339.ai_summary: Yaakov Stern, Professor and Chief of the Cognitive Neuroscience Division in Neurology at Columbia University Medical Center, focuses his research on cognitive reserve and its role in aging and Alzheimer's disease. He investigates how individual differences in cognitive processing and brain network efficiency provide resilience against age-related brain pathology, using neuroimaging and behavioral studies. His work explores proxies of cognitive reserve, such as verbal intelligence and education, and examines how these factors influence cognitive trajectories and brain function across the lifespan. Stern’s research also emphasizes the importance of longitudinal studies to better understand neural changes related to aging and cognition.

https://openalex.org/A5030503062.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5030503062.ai_summary: Dympna Casey is a Professor in the School of Nursing & Midwifery at the National University of Ireland Galway whose research focuses on the use and implementation of assistive technologies, such as social and pet robots, virtual reality, and smart wearables, to support older adults and people living with dementia. Her work explores the psychosocial impacts of these technologies, barriers and facilitators to their real-world adoption in care settings, and ethical considerations in their design and use. She employs implementation science frameworks to identify strategies that enable effective integration of technology into dementia care practices. Through qualitative studies and systematic reviews, Casey emphasizes user-centered design and stakeholder involvement to enhance technology acceptance and improve quality of life for people with dementia.

https://openalex.org/A5052217756.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5052217756.ai_summary: Sonia Ancoli-Israel, Professor of Psychiatry at the University of California San Diego, conducts research focusing on the relationships between sleep, circadian rhythms, cognitive function, and mood in older adults and clinical populations. Her work employs objective sleep measures such as actigraphy to study sleep fragmentation, circadian rhythm disturbances, and their impacts on cognition, depression, and quality of life, particularly in elderly women, patients with dementia, and breast cancer survivors. She has explored interventions like bright light therapy to improve sleep consolidation and circadian rhythms in nursing home residents. Her research also investigates complex symptom interactions involving sleep, fatigue, mood, and cognitive performance across various health conditions.

https://openalex.org/A5037109052.title: Chief Medical Officer (CMO), Senior Vice President
https://openalex.org/A5037109052.ai_summary: Harald Hampel is Chief Medical Officer and Senior Vice President of the Neurology Business Group at Eisai Inc., with extensive research focusing on Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative disorders. His work emphasizes the identification and validation of biomarkers—using neuroimaging, cerebrospinal fluid, plasma analyses, and emerging proteomic and genomic technologies—for early diagnosis, progression prediction, and therapeutic monitoring in AD and mild cognitive impairment. He also explores advanced data-driven approaches such as machine learning and systems biology to develop precision medicine frameworks tailored to individual patients. Additionally, Hampel contributes to the global effort of integrating these biomarkers into clinical trials, regulatory guidelines, and healthcare strategies aimed at improving treatment and prevention of dementia and related conditions.

https://openalex.org/A5014949118.ai_summary: Arthur W. Toga's research focuses on advanced brain imaging and computational neuroanatomy, with particular emphasis on Alzheimer's disease, brain mapping, and medical shape analysis. He has contributed to the development of imaging modalities and algorithms that enhance detection of subtle brain changes using MRI and diffusion tensor imaging, enabling detailed structural and functional analysis. His work includes automated methods for brain structure segmentation, cortical surface reconstruction, and shape modeling, employing mathematical frameworks such as conformal parameterization and Laplace-Beltrami eigen-projection. These innovations facilitate sensitive biomarkers for neurodegenerative diseases and improved statistical comparisons of brain anatomy across populations.

https://openalex.org/A5062687221.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5062687221.ai_summary: Magda Tsolaki is a Professor at the School of Medicine, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, specializing in cognitive impairment and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). Her research focuses on developing and applying advanced technologies including EEG analysis, machine learning, and smart home assistive systems for early diagnosis, continuous monitoring, and personalized interventions in cognitive disorders. She has explored digital biomarkers from behavioral and neurophysiological data to improve screening accuracy and patient quality of life. Additionally, her work encompasses investigations into cognitive impairment related to multiple sclerosis, vascular risk factors, and the cognitive effects of COVID-19.

https://openalex.org/A5051868596.title: Médicin Responsable
https://openalex.org/A5051868596.unit: Médicine Interne, Réhabilitation & Gériatrie et de Santé Mentale & Psychiatrie
https://openalex.org/A5051868596.ai_summary: Giovanni B. Frisoni is affiliated with Médicin Responsable, Médicine Interne, Réhabilitation & Gériatrie et de Santé Mentale & Psychiatrie at Hôpitaux Universitaires de Genève. His research focuses on aging, cognitive decline, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD). He has conducted extensive studies on brain aging using neuroimaging, electroencephalography (EEG), and non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) to investigate functional connectivity, cortical thickness, and biomarkers for early diagnosis and progression of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to dementia. Frisoni's work also explores the impact of sensory impairments on quality of life in elderly populations and the potential of advanced imaging and machine learning techniques for improving diagnosis and treatment strategies.

https://openalex.org/A5020791797.title: Associate Professor of Behavioural Sciences
https://openalex.org/A5020791797.ai_summary: Cindy Jones is an Associate Professor of Behavioural Sciences in the Faculty of Health Sciences & Medicine at Bond University. Her research focuses on the use of social and companion robots, particularly the therapeutic robotic seal PARO, to improve the well-being of older adults and people living with dementia. She has conducted multiple randomized controlled trials and feasibility studies exploring the effects of robotic interventions on emotional support, pain management, behavioral symptoms, and quality of life in dementia care. Her work also involves evaluating technological tools like the PainChek app to enhance pain assessment and management in residential aged care settings.

https://openalex.org/A5013257135.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5013257135.unit: Falls, Balance and Injury Research Centre
https://openalex.org/A5013257135.ai_summary: Stephen R. Lord is a Professor at the Falls, Balance and Injury Research Centre at Neuroscience Research Australia. His research focuses on the physiological and cognitive factors contributing to falls in older adults and people with neurological conditions such as Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis. He has extensively studied the roles of vision, proprioception, muscle strength, reaction time, and cognitive function in balance and gait stability, often using advanced wearable technologies and clinical assessments. His work also explores interventions to reduce fall risk, including pharmacological treatments, exercise, and the impact of assistive devices like multifocal glasses.

https://openalex.org/A5021979900.title: Professor of Neurology, Director of Research Analytics, Interdisciplinary Brain Center
https://openalex.org/A5021979900.ai_summary: Hiroko H. Dodge is a Professor of Neurology and Director of Research Analytics at the Interdisciplinary Brain Center, Harvard Medical School. Her research focuses on early detection and prediction of cognitive decline and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) utilizing diverse methodologies including machine learning, natural language processing, and multimodal AI analysis of speech and facial features. She has led longitudinal studies deploying unobtrusive home-based assessments and developed predictive tools leveraging clinical variables and electronic health records to aid in screening and monitoring Alzheimer's disease progression. Her work also explores innovative approaches combining linguistic, acoustic, and video data for improved identification of cognitive impairment in aging populations.

https://openalex.org/A5100434437.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5100434437.ai_summary: Yudong Zhang is a Professor at the School of Informatics, Capital Medical University, specializing in the development of advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques for medical image analysis. His research focuses extensively on computer-aided diagnosis systems, particularly for neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, employing methods like neural networks, support vector machines, and novel optimization algorithms. Zhang has contributed to innovations in image feature extraction, classification accuracy, and model efficiency, including applications to MRI brain scans and COVID-19 detection. His work also encompasses comprehensive reviews of deep learning approaches in medical imaging, addressing challenges and future directions in the field.

https://openalex.org/A5037128658.title: Associate Professor
https://openalex.org/A5037128658.ai_summary: Filippo Cavallo is an Associate Professor of Industrial Engineering at the University of Florence, specializing in the application of robotics, wearable sensor technologies, and ICT to healthcare and aging populations. His research spans the development and evaluation of assistive robotic systems and wearable devices for the monitoring and management of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s and dementia, focusing on early diagnosis, long-term care, and support for independent living of older adults. Cavallo has also explored innovative motor and cognitive dual-task assessments using wearable sensors to improve detection of mild cognitive impairment. His work integrates machine learning, human-robot interaction, and cloud robotics to enhance the usability, acceptance, and clinical relevance of technological solutions in healthcare.

https://openalex.org/A5035394476.title: Responsabile
https://openalex.org/A5035394476.ai_summary: Paolo Maria Rossini, Responsabile of Neuroscienze e Neuroriabilitazione at IRCCS San Raffaele Pisana, focuses his research on neurophysiological techniques such as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and EEG to explore brain function and connectivity in health and disease. His work encompasses studies on brain plasticity, cortical excitability, and network dynamics in aging, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, and the effects of neurological damage. Rossini’s team applies advanced methods including graph theory and machine learning to EEG data for early diagnosis and monitoring of neurodegenerative conditions. Additionally, he investigates neuromodulation approaches like tDCS and addresses challenges in care during events such as the COVID-19 pandemic in vulnerable elderly populations.

https://openalex.org/A5079766290.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5079766290.ai_summary: Henrik Zetterberg is a Professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Neurochemistry at the University of Gothenburg. His research primarily focuses on neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, emphasizing the identification and validation of biomarkers in cerebrospinal fluid and neuroimaging for early diagnosis, disease progression, and prognosis. He has contributed to understanding the molecular hallmarks of neurodegeneration, the interplay between depression and dementia, and the effects of sleep deprivation on neurochemical markers. His work integrates proteomic techniques and advanced biomarker discovery to inform personalized therapeutic strategies and precision medicine in neuropsychiatric disorders.

https://openalex.org/A5011354002.title: Visiting Professor
https://openalex.org/A5011354002.ai_summary: J. M. Górriz is a Visiting Professor of Psychiatry at Universidad de Granada whose research focuses on the development of computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems using advanced machine learning and deep learning techniques for neurological disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease. His work integrates neuroimaging data from modalities such as MRI, PET, and SPECT with clinical and neuropsychological information to improve early diagnosis and disease progression prediction. He has contributed to innovative approaches employing deep belief networks, convolutional autoencoders, and multimodal data fusion to enhance diagnostic accuracy and interpretability. Additionally, his research explores the broader application of deep learning in personalized health monitoring and medical image classification.

https://openalex.org/A5035103174.ai_summary: Bruce S. McEwen's research centers on the neurobiology of stress and its impact on the brain and body. He introduced key concepts such as allostasis and allostatic load to describe how the body's adaptive responses to stress can, over time, lead to wear and tear that contributes to disease. His work highlights the brain as the central organ regulating stress responses through circuits involving the hippocampus, amygdala, and prefrontal cortex, and examines how these neural systems interact bidirectionally with physiological systems. Additionally, McEwen's studies address how early life experiences, social environments, and genetic and epigenetic factors shape stress vulnerability and health outcomes across the lifespan.

https://openalex.org/A5049484291.ai_summary: Bruno Vellas's research focuses on aging-related conditions such as sarcopenia, frailty, and Alzheimer's disease, exploring their clinical manifestations and management. He has contributed to understanding the role of lifestyle and pharmacological interventions in treating sarcopenia and frailty, as well as examining behavioral and weight changes in Alzheimer's patients. Additionally, he has investigated the development and evaluation of technologies aimed at supporting healthy aging, advocating for multidisciplinary approaches tailored to the complex needs of older adults. His work also addresses methodological innovations in clinical trials and healthcare technologies within gerontology.

https://openalex.org/A5060487287.title: Joy Chambers-Grundy Professor of Brain Science; Director, Chambers-Gundy Center for Transformative Neuroscience; Co-Director, Pam Quirk Brain Health and Biomarker Laboratory
https://openalex.org/A5060487287.unit: School of Integrated Health Sciences / Department of Brain Health
https://openalex.org/A5060487287.ai_summary: Jeffrey L. Cummings is the Joy Chambers-Grundy Professor of Brain Science and serves as Director of the Chambers-Gundy Center for Transformative Neuroscience as well as Co-Director of the Pam Quirk Brain Health and Biomarker Laboratory at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. His research focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer’s disease (AD), examining drug development pipelines, clinical trials, and biomarkers to improve diagnosis and treatment. He has also contributed to understanding frontal lobe function and executive control in various neuropsychiatric conditions, and explores precision medicine approaches and affective computing applications for late-life mood and cognitive disorders. His work includes developing predictive algorithms to enhance the efficiency of AD clinical trial recruitment and studying sex differences in brain connectivity related to AD vulnerability.

https://openalex.org/A5000597778.title: Hugh Monroe Wilson Professor of Radiology
https://openalex.org/A5000597778.ai_summary: Tammie L.S. Benzinger is the Hugh Monroe Wilson Professor of Radiology at the Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology, Washington University in St. Louis. Her research focuses on using advanced neuroimaging techniques, including resting-state functional MRI and positron emission tomography, to study the brain’s functional networks and biomarkers in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), particularly autosomal dominant AD (ADAD). She employs machine learning and deep learning models to analyze longitudinal imaging and biomarker data, aiming to predict disease progression and identify key neurobiological changes. Her work contributes to understanding the systems-level pathology of AD and improving tracking of disease stages through integrative multimodal approaches.

https://openalex.org/A5084122016.title: Research Director
https://openalex.org/A5084122016.ai_summary: Ioannis Kompatsiaris is Research Director at the Information Technologies Institute, Centre for Research and Technology-Hellas. His research focuses on developing intelligent systems and sensor technologies for ambient assisted living, with an emphasis on monitoring and improving the quality of life of elderly people and those with cognitive impairments such as dementia and Alzheimer's disease. He has contributed to wearable and smart home technologies for continuous health monitoring, activity recognition, and stress detection, as well as AI and signal processing methods for multilingual dementia assessment through speech analysis. His work also explores the integration of multimodal sensor data and the applicability of assistive technologies in clinical and caregiving contexts.

https://openalex.org/A5060242044.org: Yeshiva University Albert Einstein College of Medicine
https://openalex.org/A5060242044.ai_summary: Joe Verghese's research focuses on the relationships among gait, cognition, and aging in older adults. His work extensively explores quantitative gait markers as predictors of falls, cognitive decline, and dementia, including the development of the Motoric Cognitive Risk syndrome as a clinical tool for early identification of dementia risk. He investigates neural substrates of gait and social support using neuroimaging, highlighting how mobility and social factors relate to brain networks and cognitive health. Verghese also examines executive functions and dual-tasking effects on gait, contributing to understanding mobility impairments and potential intervention targets in aging populations.

https://openalex.org/A5014517165.org: National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology
https://openalex.org/A5014517165.ai_summary: Takanori Shibata's research focuses on the development and application of therapeutic robots, particularly the seal robot PARO, designed to support elderly individuals, including those with dementia. His work investigates the psychological, physiological, and social effects of human-robot interaction, demonstrating benefits such as improved mood, reduced stress, and decreased caregiver burden. Shibata has conducted extensive studies in care facilities and home settings, exploring how PARO facilitates communication, engagement, and therapy as a nonpharmacological tool. His research also addresses practical considerations for integrating robotic therapy into elder care environments with professional support.

https://openalex.org/A5040635626.ai_summary: Sandra E. Black’s research focuses on neurological conditions affecting cognitive function, particularly Alzheimer’s disease, mild cognitive impairment, stroke, and cerebral small vessel disease. Her work investigates biomarkers, neuroimaging techniques, and machine learning models to improve diagnosis, track disease progression, and understand underlying pathophysiological mechanisms. She explores multimodal approaches including genomics, metabolomics, and neuroimaging, as well as practical interventions like exercise programs and memory-supporting technologies to enhance quality of life in affected populations. Her studies span from advanced imaging methodologies to clinical applications aimed at personalized medicine and rehabilitation.

https://openalex.org/A5025313057.ai_summary: Kaj Blennow is a researcher specializing in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and neurodegenerative disorders, with a focus on identifying and validating biomarkers for early diagnosis, progression, and prognosis. His work encompasses proteomic analyses of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), neuroimaging techniques, and the investigation of neuroinflammation and neurochemical markers related to AD and mild cognitive impairment. He has also explored the relationships between vascular health, overweight, depression, and their impacts on dementia risk. His research contributes to improving diagnostic approaches and understanding the molecular and clinical pathways in dementia and related cognitive disorders.

https://openalex.org/A5048183050.title: Regents Professor and Huie-Rogers Chair

https://openalex.org/A5089758511.title: Professor

He applies advanced methodologies including machine learning to improve dementia prediction and diagnosis accuracy. Llewellyn also utilizes large-scale datasets like the UK Biobank to study genetic, environmental, and lifestyle interactions, advancing understanding of dementia prevention and clinical decision-making.

https://openalex.org/A5048756832.ai_summary: Alexandra König's research focuses on the use of information and communication technology, particularly automated speech and facial expression analysis, to improve detection, assessment, and monitoring of neuropsychiatric symptoms and cognitive decline in older adults with dementia and related disorders. Her work explores the development of remote and cost-effective tools, such as telephone-based cognitive screening and telemedicine platforms, leveraging machine learning to analyze vocal and nonverbal markers related to apathy, depression, anxiety, and cognitive impairment. She also investigates personalized approaches in assistive technologies for Alzheimer's patients by considering affective identities. Overall, her research aims to enhance early diagnosis, continuous symptom monitoring, and clinical trial recruitment through innovative, user-centered digital health solutions.

https://openalex.org/A5025003387.title: Associate Director
https://openalex.org/A5025003387.org: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
https://openalex.org/A5025003387.ai_summary: James B. Rowe is Associate Director of Experimental Medicine at Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust. His research focuses on using advanced neuroimaging techniques, particularly magnetoencephalography (MEG), to study brain network disruptions in neurodegenerative dementias such as Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies. He investigates the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying cognitive deficits through analysis of brain connectivity, oscillatory dynamics, and predictive coding frameworks. Additionally, Rowe develops novel imaging biomarkers and datasets to improve early diagnosis and inform experimental medicine approaches for dementia.

https://openalex.org/A5059027860.title: Professor
https://openalex.org/A5059027860.ai_summary: David S. Knopman is a Professor of Neurology at Mayo Clinic Rochester whose research focuses on the relationships between brain changes and cognitive as well as motor function in aging populations. His work investigates the effects of hearing impairment and white matter hyperintensities on cognitive decline, memory, executive function, and motor abilities in elderly individuals without dementia. He has also explored innovative applications of artificial intelligence and natural language processing to support caregivers of Alzheimer's disease patients by automatically generating answers to their questions. Overall, his research aims to better understand neurological changes associated with aging and dementia to inform potential interventions.

https://openalex.org/A5030612566.title: professor
https://openalex.org/A5030612566.ai_summary: Alice Nieuwboer is a professor of Rehabilitation Science at KU Leuven specializing in Parkinson’s disease (PD) research, with a focus on gait disorders such as freezing of gait (FOG) and fall prevention. Her work integrates assessments of motor and cognitive impairments, the application of wearable technology, and machine learning to better understand and manage PD symptoms. Nieuwboer also investigates rehabilitation methods including rhythmic auditory cueing, motor imagery, and visual cueing to improve motor function and reduce disability in PD patients. Additionally, she explores neural network connectivity and physical activity factors to optimize neurorehabilitation strategies in this population.

https://openalex.org/A5021394368.ai_summary: John Q. Trojanowski’s research focuses on Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related neurodegenerative disorders, with a particular emphasis on biomarker development, disease heterogeneity, and clinical-pathological correlations. He has contributed to characterizing neuroanatomical and biochemical patterns in AD using advanced imaging, cerebrospinal fluid biomarkers, and machine learning to improve diagnosis, prognosis, and patient stratification. His work also explores the vascular contributions to dementia, exemplified by studies of atrial fibrillation’s impact on AD clinical profiles. Additionally, Trojanowski has been involved in developing and validating precise bioanalytical methods for plasma biomarkers and advancing integrated models for AD care and therapeutic development.

https://openalex.org/A5072151058.title: Associate professor of Neurology
https://openalex.org/A5072151058.ai_summary: Flavio Nobili is an Associate Professor of Neurology in the Department of Neuroscience (DINOGMI) at the University of Genoa. His research focuses on neurological complications associated with diseases such as COVID-19, including cognitive impairment and neuroinflammation effects on the frontal lobes. He also works on the development of flexible, extensible data models and distributed databases that integrate clinical, imaging, and molecular data to support multidisciplinary neuroscience research. His efforts include creating adaptable software environments that enable dynamic data type definition and facilitate complex patient-centered diagnostic processes.
